market_summary: Markets sold off sharply: SPY -1.45%, QQQ -1.91%, IWM -2.72% despite strong jobs report
Mag 7 AI capex plans totaling $680B remain in focus; Goldman flagging potential rotation to 'old economy' stocks
Energy sector outperforming with XOM +24% and CVX +19% YTD; Chevron hit 52-week high on Libya oil win

thesis: Explosive earnings growth: Q1 FY26 EPS of $4.60 vs $1.41 year-ago; revenue up 69% YoY to $13.6B with 56% gross margin
Attractive valuation with strong revisions: Forward P/E ~13x on FY26 consensus EPS of $32.04, rising to $42.30 in FY27 (+32% growth); PEG ratio of ~1.0
AI memory supercycle: HBM demand from data centers driving structural growth; multiple analysts highlighting MU as undervalued commodity-multiple stock despite AI tailwinds
risks: Memory cyclicality: Historical boom-bust cycles in DRAM/NAND could compress margins if AI demand slows
Customer concentration: Heavy reliance on hyperscaler capex which could face cuts if macro deteriorates
China exposure: Trade tensions and potential export restrictions remain ongoing overhang
falsifiable_checks: Q2 FY26 earnings (late March) should show sequential revenue growth and maintained/expanded gross margins above 50%
HBM revenue guidance for FY26 should remain above $5B with expanding market share vs SK Hynix
trade_of_the_day.why_now: MU trades at ~39x trailing P/E but only ~13x forward on FY26 estimates, reflecting massive earnings inflection. Consensus EPS revisions have been sharply positive (FY27 at $42+ implies 32% growth). The stock pulled back on Monday providing entry opportunity. Memory supercycle driven by AI infrastructure buildout has 12-18 month runway as hyperscalers execute on $680B capex plans. Value + Revisions strategy captures both the discount to intrinsic value and positive estimate momentum.
